data.question: What is the parent compound of the investigated species?
data.answer: Cu(I) catenate (RuCu)

data.question: What method was used to selectively demetalate the Cu(I) catenate moiety of RuCu?
data.answer: Selective demetalation was achieved by reaction with KCN in MeCN−H2O.

data.question: What are the two new bimetallic catenates obtained by reacting the catenand with Ag+ and Zn2+ ions?
data.answer: RuAg and RuZn

data.question: What technique was used to determine the solid-state structure of complexes RuCu and RuAg?
data.answer: X-ray diffraction

data.question: What phenomenon is observed in the photophysical properties of Ru, RuCu, RuZn, and RuAg?
data.answer: Efficient photoinduced intercomponent energy- and/or electron-transfer processes

data.question: What happens to the energy-transfer direction by changing the catenate metal ion?
data.answer: The direction of the energy-transfer can be controlled.

data.question: Is the absorption spectra of the dinuclear species a simple sum of the spectra of the model compounds?
data.answer: Yes, the spectra of the dinuclear species practically correspond to the sum of the spectra of the model compounds.

data.question: Does the presence of Ag+ or Zn2+ ions in the [2]-cat-type moiety affect the ground-state electronic interactions?
data.answer: No, the absorption spectra do not show any appreciable ground-state electronic interactions between the [2]-catM and [Ru(tpy)2]2+-type moieties.

data.question: Can the rate constant of intercomponent processes be determined via time-resolved luminescence spectroscopy?
data.answer: Yes, the rate constant of intercomponent processes are determined via time-resolved nano- and picosecond luminescence spectroscopy.

data.question: What is the effect of changing the metal ion in the catenate moiety on the luminescence properties?
data.answer: Changing the metal ion in the catenate moiety can reverse the direction of the quenching observed in the luminescence properties.

data.question: Is the [Ru(tpy)2]2+ unit always the quencher in the investigated compounds?
data.answer: No, for RuCu the opposite behavior is observed where the [Ru(tpy)2]2+ unit is quenched by the catenate moiety.

data.question: Does the presence of Ag+ ion in RuAg lead to a different luminescence behavior compared to RuCu?
data.answer: Yes, the presence of Ag+ ion in RuAg leads to a different luminescence behavior compared to RuCu.

data.question: What is the role of KCN in the synthesis of the catenand Ru from RuCu?
data.answer: KCN is used to selectively remove the copper(I) without affecting the Ru complex, leading to the catenand Ru.

data.question: Are the electrochemical experiments performed under an inert atmosphere?
data.answer: Yes, all measurements were carried out under Ar.

data.question: Does the synthesis of RuZn involve the use of Zn(NO3)2·3H2O?
data.answer: Yes, Zn(NO3)2·3H2O is used in the synthesis of RuZn.

data.question: Is the synthesis of RuAg achieved by adding AgBF4 to a solution of Ru?
data.answer: Yes, AgBF4 is added to a solution of Ru to synthesize RuAg.

data.question: Can the synthesis conditions of RuCu and RuZn be found in the same reference?
data.answer: No, the synthesis conditions of RuCu and RuZn are reported in different references.

data.question: Is the luminescence of RuCu at 77 K characterized by a strong emission band?
data.answer: Yes, RuCu shows a strong emission band at 77 K.

data.question: Does the synthesis of RuAg result in a quantitative yield?
data.answer: Yes, the synthesis of RuAg results in a quantitative yield.

data.question: Are the photophysical investigations performed using a Perkin-Elmer λ5 spectrophotometer?
data.answer: Yes, absorption spectra were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer λ5 spectrophotometer.
